greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Decimal expansion of the constant x whose continued fraction expansion equals A006519 (highest power of 2 dividing n).
comment: This constant x has the special property that the continued fraction expansion of 2*x results in the continued fraction expansion of x interleaved with 2's: contfrac(x) = [1;2,1,4,1,2,1,8,1,2,1,4,1,2,1,16,...A006519(n),... ] while contfrac(2*x) = [2;1, 2,2, 2,1, 2,4, 2,1, 2,2, 2,1, 2,8,... 2, A006519(n),...].
The continued fraction of x^2 has large partial quotients (see A100864, A100865) that appear to be doubly exponential.
link: Dzmitry Badziahin, Jeffrey Shallit, An Unusual Continued Fraction, arXiv:1505.00667 [math.NT], 2015.
mathematica: cf = ContinuedFraction[ Table[ 2^IntegerExponent[n, 2], {n, 1, 200}]]; RealDigits[ FromContinuedFraction[cf // Flatten] , 10, 105] // First (* _Jean-François Alcover_, Feb 19 2013 *)
program: (PARI) /* This PARI code generates 1000 digits of x very quickly: */ {x=sqrt(2);y=x;L=2^10;for(i=1,10,v=contfrac(x,2*L); if(2*L>#v,v=concat(v,vector(2*L-#v+1,j,1))); if(2*L>#w,w=concat(w,vector(2*L-#w+1,j,1))); w=vector(2*L,n,if(n%2==1,2,w[n]=v[n\2]));w[1]=floor(2*x); CFW=contfracpnqn(w);x=CFW[1,1]/CFW[2,1]*1.0/2;);x}
results.author: _Paul D. Hanna_, Nov 17 2004
